A local newscaster claims that if the coffee fountain were to break, the 400 gallons of coffee it contains would cover half of a city block. However, based upon my calculations of the dispersion of the 400 gallons of coffee contained, I have found this claim to be completely invalid. Here are my calculations:

One city block: 900,000 square feet

----> half of a city block: 450,000 square feet

One gallon of dispersed water covers about 13.8 square feet

Thus, 400 gallons of water would cover 5520 square feet. This is a stunning 81 times less area than the newscaster reported! This amount does not even come close to the original claim.

No, clearly this news reporter doesn't have her facts straight. She could have been using hyperbole in her statement as to get a better reaction from her audience, however. Clearly she didn't research physics and how much space 1 gallon of fluid covers. But, if we are going to go along with this based on mathematics and physics rather than reason, thus can be said:

    Assuming that the basic laws of physics apply in this universe of lies and deceit, we can say that there is an infinitely small chance that all of the molecules of coffee will bypass the ground completely and sink into the earth. This is due to the basic law that molecules move around eachother; it is possible for one molecule to move out of the way and allow the passage of 1 molecule of coffee. With this in mind, we can state that there is a chance that ALL of the molecules of coffee can bypass the floor and instead move straight into the ground. If we think about it this way, the news reporter could be entirely justified in their statement that the coffee would cover half a block of space. The rest of the coffee could simply go underground, never to be seen again. Though highly unlikely, it is possible. Please give me your thoughts on this concept.

    However given the nature of this question and assuming that this giant coffee pot really can be suspended in the air by Quantum Physics or another science of that nature, I would say that no, the coffee will not cover the entire block. I would also say that the ground must be made of some sort of cooling plates that empower the magnatism required to suspend the atoms of the coffee pot in space. Four Hundred gallons of coffee is not even close to the amount it will take to cover even one fourth of a city block. A city block covers near to ninety-thousand square feet! However the amount of coffee that the cup holds, four hundred gallons, only covers approximately sixty-one thousandths of a city block, which is only 5,520 square feet. The math is simple as the average city block is three hundred by three hundred feet, therefore when you multiply it's length and width, a city block covers ninety thousand square feet. One gallon of water covers 13.8 square feet, and the coffee cup holds four hundred gallons, therefore four hundred multiplied by 13.8 is 5,520, which is not even close to 90,000.
